newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Belgium seizes 13 tonnes of Cambodian cannabis.
newsitem.headline: Belgium seizes 13 tonnes of Cambodian cannabis.

text.p: Police in the Belgian port of Anvers seized more than 13 tonnes of cannabis in a textiles shipment from Cambodia, an evening paper reported on Wednesday.
Cambodia Soir quoted an Interior Ministry official as saying Cambodian police had launched a local investigation after news of the discovery on August 17 of 13,320 kilogrammes of cannabis.

The newspaper noted that police in the Mauritanian capital Nouakchott had on August 11 seized almost seven tonnes of drugs on a container believed to have orginated in Cambodia and carried on the ship Maersk Douala.
"The cannabis was hidden among cartons of T-shirts in a container," the ministry official told the French-language paper, adding that an unidentified garment company could be behind the shipment.
The container was loaded in the coastal port of Sihanoukville and transited Singapore en route for Anvers.

"This massive haul, the second in less than a week, tends to show that Cambodia is becoming an important producer of cannabis," he said, adding that drug dealers had expanded beyond the traditional market in Thailand.

U.S. anti-narcotics officials say Cambodia is becoming a major transshipment point for drugs, especially narcotics originating from the Golden Traingle area bordering Burma, Laos and Thailand and bound mainly for North America and Europe.
Easrlier this year, the Clinton administration added Cambodia to a list of countries thought to be trafficking in drugs or being used to transship narcotics.
Cambodian authorities had until recently treated marijuana as a spice, which was particularly popular in soups and was openly available in Phnom Penh markets.
